p.s: Lady Macbeth tries to persuade her husband Macbeth.
But she does not really try to convince him with arguments but by manipulating him.
That is especially seen when you take a look at her choice of language.
As Macbeth tries to stop her from her thoughts, she uses a personification in line 8 to 9.
She asks him if his hope was drunk when they made plans together.
In connection to this, she also uses an anticlimax (l. 9 to 11).
She criticizes that he seemingly lost his ambition to murder the kingKing and even says she valued his love then.
With that she presents the act of murdering the kingKing as a very simple thing and even manipulates him as she tries to make him emotional by bringing in their love to each other.
After that she insults him and tries to convince him that the reason for his doubt was his low self-esteem as she thinks he would see himself as a coward (l. 16) if he did not do it.
Lady Macbeth also compares him to a cat, that does not want to get its paws wet, which is a proverb (l. 18), and wants to make him look lazy or ungreatful.
After she still does not want to go that far, she uses an exaggeration/hyperbole [...] beast [...] ( l. 24) while she is talking about his earlier attitude.
A climax follows after that as she says that he was a man when he had that attitude and would be way more of a man if he did murder the kingKing (l. 25 to 28).
Manipulating him even more, she goes further and compares her love to him to her love to a baby that she breastfed (l. 31 to 35).
That leaves the impression that she tries to convince him to believe that she could love him as much as possible if he was brave enough to do it.
Answering Macbeth's question If we should fail? (l. 38), she explains her exact plan to him.
She makes it seem like his fear is the only possible reason for failure (l. 39 to 41) and tells him that she would make Duncan's guards drunk while he is asleep (l. 41ff.).
She uses a metaphor in line 48 as she says that their brain should be a limbeck when she makes them drunk.
So it seems that she wants to make them drunk really bad.
That is also shown by the hyperbole she uses.
She says that they would [...] lie as in a death [...] (l. 49) which is also a comparismcomparison.
She clearly exaggerates and wants Macbeth to believe that there could nothing go wrong.
This gets also clear in the last lines (l. 50 to 53) because she asks him rhetoric questions.
Accepting her plan and thinking it would work like that, there is nothing he can answer on these questions.
She simply asks him what they could not do to DuncardDuncan in this situation and who would find them guilty if there was nobody to see.
That leaves again the impression that killing Duncan is a simple thing to her.
